sen.j: 結城 無二三（ゆうき むにぞう・弘化2年4月17日 (旧暦)（1845年5月22日） - 明治45年（1912年）5月17日）は、京都見廻組及び新選組の元隊士だと主張していた人物。
sen.e: Munizo Yuki (May 22, 1845-May 17, 1912) was the person, who claimed himself as the former soldier of the Kyoto Mimawarigumi (the group who patrolled Kyoto) as well as the Shinsengumi.

sen.j: 幼名の「有無之助」は「俺ほどの豪傑が世の中に有るか無いか」という意味で、「無二三」とは「俺ほどの豪傑は天下に二人も三人も居ない」という意味で名乗ったという。
sen.e: His childhood name, "Umunosuke" meant "there is a person or none, who is as bold as me in this world" and "Munizo" means "there are no two or three people in this tenka (country) as bold as me."

sen.j: 坂本暗殺事件は慶応3年11月15日に起きたが、この日、新選組の主だった人々は伊東甲子太郎一派を粛清するために話し合いをしていた。
sen.e: The Assassination of Sakamoto occurred in November 15, 1867, but people, who were the owners of Shinsengumi were discussing to purge the fraction of Kashitaro ITO.

sen.j: 幹部が動いていないのに隊士が動くわけは無く、新選組は坂本殺害とは無関係とする主張。
sen.e: It was a claim that Shinsengumi and the murder of Sakamoto were unrelated because there was no reason that the soldiers would act while their leaders did not move.

sen.j: 元々、中国語から訳した聖書を読み物として持っていたが、明治11年（1878年）暮れに夫婦とも高熱により乳飲み児の世話すら出来ない危機を祈りによって脱した経験からキリスト教に関心を持ち、同年7月に甲州桜町に講義所を開いていたカナダの宣教師CSイビー(Charles.S.Eby) のもとを翌年訪れ、その教えに感銘を受け授洗。
sen.e: Originally, he read the Bible that he translated from Chinese as a reading material but became interested in Christianity when he prayed and escaped from crisis when the couple could not take care of the toddler from having a high fever at the end of 1878, visited the lecture hall of Canadian missionary, Charles S. Eby, who opened the lecture hall in Koshusakura town in July 1878, and was deeply moved by the teachings that he was christened.

sen.e: Even though Christianity practice was legalized once the Meiji Period began, it was a period when cities despised Christianity as "yaso" (slang for Christianity) and claimed that Christians "eat the liver of a living child" or "uses bad magic" but he devoted himself to missionary works and actually achieved spreading Christianity especially in areas of Shizuoka and Yamanashi Prefectures.

sen.e: Munizo was stimulated by the movement of Joi ha (an exclusionist) such as Namamugi Incident, and recruited comrades to perform the exclusion of foreigners himself, but was discovered by bakufu that he escaped from Edo and moved to Kyoto in order to flee from his captors.

sen.j: 文久3年（1863年）または元治元年（1864年）、有無之助は京都へ行くが、攘夷とは名ばかりの暴徒が多いことに絶望、それらを懲らす志を立て江戸からの知人であった村田作郎を頼り、彼が肝煎を務める京都見廻組の寄宿人（幕臣ではない隊士）となる。
sen.e: Munizo went to Kyoto in either 1863 or 1864, but was devastated when he learned that there were violent groups, who excluded foreigners in name only, and became Kishukunin (the boarder) (the soldier who was not Bakushin) who took care of Kyoto Mimawarigumi in order to punish those people by asking for the help of Sakuro MURATA, who was his acquaintance from when they were in Edo.

Munizo went to Kyoto in either 1863 or 1864, but was devastated when he learned that there were violent groups, who excluded foreigners in name only, and became Kishukunin (the boarder) (the soldier who was not Bakushin) who took care of Kyoto Mimawarigumi in order to punish those people by asking for the help of Sakuro MURATA, who was an acquaintance of his from when they were in Edo.

Umunosuke went to Kyoto in either 1863 or 1864, but was devastated when he learned that there were violent groups, who excluded foreigners in name only, and became Kishukunin (the boarder) (the soldier who was not Bakushin) who took care of Kyoto Mimawarigumi in order to punish those people by asking for the help of Sakuro MURATA, who was an acquaintance of his from when they were in Edo.
sen.cmt: Munizo を Umunosuke に修正

sen.j: この頃、後に日本メソジスト教会日下部教会（現・日本キリスト教団日下部教会）の主要メンバーとなる飯島信明・中沢徳兵衛らを信者とする。
sen.e: At this time, he converted Nobuaki IIJIMA and Tokubei NAKAZAWA, who later became the head members of the Japanese Methodist Church Kusakabe Church (Current United Church of Christ in Japan, Kusakabe Church), as believers.

sen.j: 明治23年（1890年）頃、北巨摩郡韮崎市に移り、講義所を開く。
sen.e: 1890: He moved to Nirasaki city, Kitakoma District and established a lecture hall.

sen.j: この頃、貧窮（主に「伝道士」が入信者に与えられる役割となり収益が減ったのと、家族が増加して支出が増したのが理由）のため妻子を甲府へ送り出し、独り韮崎に残る。
sen.e: At this time, he sent his wife and children to Kofu due to poverty (Since"missionary" became a position given to new believers and his income lessend as well as the family members increased along with consumption) and stayed alone at Nirasaki.

sen.j: イビイ宣教師再来日、東京本郷 (文京区)へ中央会堂を建てるも、火災により焼失。
sen.e: When Eby missionary came to Japan again, he built the Chuokaido at Hongo, Tokyo (Bunkyo Ward) but burnt down due to fire.

When Eby missionary came to Japan again, he built the Chuo kaido at Hongo, Tokyo (Bunkyo Ward) but it was burnt down due to fire.

sen.j: イビイ宣教師は帰国の上、資金集めに奔走。
sen.e: Eby missionary went all over the place to receive donations when he returned back to his home country.

sen.j: 明治25年（1892年）、本郷中央会堂完成、イビイ宣教師が無二三を招くが、教会の意向に従い韮崎に残る。
sen.e: 1892: Eby missionary invited Munizo once the Hongo Chukaido was completed, but he decided to stay in Nirasaki from the will of the church.

sen.e: March 1893: Munizo went to Tokyo and worked under Eby missionary and built a dorm which eventually became the "Keimei kan."

sen.j: 無二三は寄宿舎を下宿とし家賃収入によって生計を立てることとなる。
sen.e: Munizo made the boarding house as a lodging and made a living by collecting rental fee.

sen.j: 明治28年（1895年）、無二三の窮状を見かねた寄宿生たちは負担軽減のために寄宿舎より転宿、無二三も両門町・岩崎弥太郎邸（現・東京都文京区湯島。但し、岩崎邸完成は翌1896年で、この頃は建設中と思われる）裏にて改めて下宿屋を開く。
sen.e: 1895: Boarders, who saw the wretched condition of Munizo decided to move away from the boarding house to lessen the burden, and Munizo used the back og the residence of Yataro IWASAKI in Ryomo Town (Currently Yushima, Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo.

However, the residence of Iwasaki was completed in the following 1896, and it is believed that it was still under construction at this time) to create a boarding house.

sen.e: In 1895, boarders, who saw the wretched condition of Munizo, decided to move away from the boarding house to lessen the burden, and Munizo used the back of the residence of Yataro IWASAKI in Ryomo Town (currently in Yushima, Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo; the residence of IWASAKI was completed in the following 1896, and it is believed that it was still under construction then) to create a boarding house.

sen.j: しかしここも長く続かず、下谷黒門町へ菓子屋を開いたが隣家が老舗の菓子屋だったため再び移転、本郷森川町に菓子屋を開業する。
sen.e: However, this did not last long, and opened up a sweet shop in Shitaya Kuromon town but the next door was the long established sweet shop that he moved to Hongo Morikawa town and opened up the sweet shop.

sen.j: ここで水飴に牛乳を入れた工夫菓子によって好調となるが、私食などによって経営負担が増大したため再度移転、本郷湯島新花町に駄菓子屋を開くが、これもうまくはいかなかった。
sen.e: Here, the shop prospered due to the creative sweet that mixed milk into millet jelly, but the stress on the store management increased due to eating samples and transferred again to open a cheap sweet shop but did not go well.

sen.j: 商売に見切りをつけ、再び伝道士として下谷根岸講義所へ配属されるが、飯島信明・中沢徳兵衛らに強請され、甲州へ戻る。
sen.e: He decided to end the merchandizing work and was reassigned as the missionary in Shitaya negishi kogisho (Shitaya Negishi Lecture Hall) but was pleaded greatly by Nobuaki IIJIMA and Tokubei NAKAZAWA that he returned to Koshu.
